content: Bridge in Singapore 1°17′27.3″N 103°50′38.4″E﻿ / ﻿1.290917°N 103.844000°E﻿ / 1.290917; 103.844000 **Ord Bridge** ([Chinese](/wiki/Simplified_Chinese): 渥桥) is a [pedestrian](/wiki/Pedestrian) [bridge](/wiki/Bridge) in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore). It spans the [Singapore River](/wiki/Singapore_River) at [Clarke Quay](/wiki/Clarke_Quay), located in the [Singapore River Planning Area](/wiki/Singapore_River_Planning_Area) within the [Central Area](/wiki/Central_Area,_Singapore). The Ord Bridge was built in 1886 to replace a demolished [footbridge](/wiki/Footbridge) known as the ABC Bridge. The [steel](/wiki/Steel) [truss](/wiki/Truss) bridge was named after [Colonel](/wiki/Colonel) [Sir](/wiki/Sir) [Harry St. George Ord](/wiki/Harry_Ord) (1819–1885), the first [British](/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland) [Governor of the Straits Settlements](/wiki/Governor_of_the_Straits_Settlements) (1867–1873) after it was given the [Crown Colony](/wiki/Crown_Colony) status. The new name was also an [abbreviation](/wiki/Abbreviation) of its old name, **Ordnance Bridge**, which was a reference to the British ordnance depot along Magazine Road. It was also known as **Toddy Bridge** as there were *[toddy](/wiki/Palm_wine)* shops in nearby [Pulau Saigon](/wiki/Pulau_Saigon), an [island](/wiki/Island) on Singapore River which has since been [reclaimed](/wiki/Land_reclamation). Now it is commonly referred to as ORD bridge in relation to National servicemen reaching their operationally ready date, and celebrating at the bridge itself On 3 November 2008, the bridge was selected for conservation as part of the [Urban Redevelopment Authority](/wiki/Urban_Redevelopment_Authority)'s expanded conservation programme. - [List of bridges in Singapore](/wiki/List_of_bridges_in_Singapore) - National Heritage Board (2006), *Discover Singapore - Heritage Trails*, [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 981-05-6433-3 - Victor R Savage, Brenda S A Yeoh (2004), *Toponymics - A Study of Singapore Street Names*, Eastern University Press, [ISBN](/wiki/ISBN_(identifier)) 981-210-364-3 This article about a Singapore building or structure is a stub.
